summary: introduction Kawasaki disease (KD) most commonly develops in infants. the specific cause of KD is still unclear, but some reports suggest that it is triggered by bacterial or viral infections. a 37-year-old, previously healthy man was admitted to our hospital 12 days after developing a fever of 38°C and erythema of the hands, arms, and legs. he was treated with 300 mg/day of cefcapene-pivoxil and 60 mg/day of loxoprofen, but his condition did not improve. he was eventually referred to our hospital for close examination and treatment. atous erythema was noted on his trunk, extremities, axillae, flank, and hip. there was also brawny edema of the hands and feet and marked congestion of the conjunctivae. his lips were reddish, dry, and swollen, and his palatine tonsils were slightly red. myalgia, congested conjunctivae, erythema, and desquamations were resolved. the treatment was switched from aspirin to 200 mg/day of cilostazol. transthoracic echocardiography revealed no coronary aneurysms.
